title: Friday, 28th April, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:01am

Hi there

PM11:01am

Yes, we'll have to talk about banks

PM11:01am

And we'll have to talk about the sudden realisation that we voted Brexit

11:01 am
PM11:01am

But it's Friday

PM11:02am

And it's a bank holiday weekend

PM11:02am

So have a picture of a ceiling light

11:02 am
PM11:02am

PM11:02am

I hate these things

PM11:02am

I have them in my kitchen, but they screw up the ceiling plaster

11:02 am
PM11:02am

When you change the bulbs

PM11:03am

But we need to discuss, cos this is today's major mover

PM11:03am

Photonstar LED

11:03 am
Photonstar Led Group PLC (PSL:LSE): Last: 2.71, up 2.14 (+371.48%), High: 2.77, Low: 2.01, Volume: 18.13m
PM11:03am

Yes, really

PM11:03am

This is pure dot comedy stuff

11:03 am
PM11:04am

The connected lightbulb

PM11:04am

Internet of things

PM11:04am

Charted

11:04 am
PM11:04am

PM11:04am

Maybe you need some historical perspective

PM11:04am

11:04 am
PM11:05am

Floated as Enfis group http://www.investe...0703230800025449T/

PM11:05am

A decade ago

PM11:05am

And now it's finally found share price traction with the IoT

11:05 am
PM11:05am

http://www.investe...1704280700096126D/

PM11:05am

PhotonStar LED Group Plc (AIM: PSL, "PhotonStar" or "the Company"), the British designer and manufacturer of intelligent lighting and building control solutions is pleased to announce that it has received a letter of intent (the "LoI") regarding the proposed roll out of the halcyonPRO2 and its halcyon CloudBMS platform.

PM11:06am

The LoI has been received from a leading manager and developer of student accommodation in the UK (the "Customer") following a 9 month trial period that commenced in July 2016. During the trial period the Company's Halcyon Internet of Things ("IoT") platforms were installed to evaluate the use of Halcyon in reducing the operating costs of the accommodation buildings for the Customer. The initial trial incorporated 167 rooms on one site and demonstrated significant maintenance savings to the Customer.

11:06 am
PM11:06am

Good luck with that

PM11:06am

LED bulbs are awful, no?

PM11:07am

And ceiling downlights screw the plaster ceiling. Dreadful things

11:07 am
BE11:07am

No. So I know "these newfangled lightbulbs are awful" was a main pillar of the Brexit vote, but I do tend to disagree.

PM11:08am

It's cold white light. Makes people look ill.

PM11:08am

Fine in cars etc. But kitchens? Front rooms?

11:08 am
BE11:08am

No, it doesn't. LED comes in a wider spectrum than incandescent.

BE11:09am

I know there's something very Daily Mail comments about moaning about lightbulbs. What the moans tend to mean is "I bought the cheapest ones from Poundstretcher and I don't like them."

PM11:09am

I've tried a range - cheap to expensive. All awful

11:09 am
BE11:10am

You've done it wrong then. I suggest you speak to a specialist such as .... I dunno, Photonstar?

BE11:10am

(Not an investment recommendation, please note.)

undefined
11:10 am
PM11:10am

We just going to have to disagree on that and talk about banks instead

PM11:10am

Footsie off

PM11:11am

Sterling being even more like sterling

11:10 am
PM11:11am

What the hell is going on with it

PM11:11am

Threatening to go back thru 1.30

BE11:11am

Speaking of banks, as we were about to ... HSBC just crossing the tape saying they've moving 1k jobs to Paris.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

As in, from London.

BE11:12am

I'll go! I mean, I don't work for HSBC, but I'll go anyway.

HSBC Holdings PLC (HSBA:LSE): Last: 636.80, down 3.9 (-0.61%), High: 641.90, Low: 636.30, Volume: 4.83m
11:12 am
PM11:12am

Better than Frankfurt, that's for sure

BE11:12am

Otherwise, it's a somewhat mixed results day.

Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 211.45, down 12.5 (-5.58%), High: 217.95, Low: 211.40, Volume: 32.94m
11:13 am
PM11:13am

Actually, if all the business moves to Paris maybe we should move as well

BE11:14am

So, rather than get distracted with regards which bit of Paris I'd want to live (probably St Martin, since you ask) ... Barclays.

BE11:14am

Q1 slightly better than consensus.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Pretax £1.7bn vs £1.5bn consensus.

PM11:15am

It's so difficult to work through these figures

BE11:15am

Banking fee income up 51%.

11:15 am
BE11:16am

But you then have to move down to the attributable profit line to strip out the one-offs and junk ......

PM11:16am

Such as Africa etc

BE11:16am

Yup ........... including a £884m impairment on BAGL.

11:16 am
PM11:17am

This should have been well flagged though -- given that the African biz is listed in JoBurg

BE11:17am

Yep, should be mark to market. Not sure why it caught anyone unawares.

PM11:17am

(Agreed GBKrona. Longer term i think they will regret selling)

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Rather than have me chew through the figures, have RBC to do so in a more professional manner.

BE11:18am

Barclays' Q1 figures were broadly in line with expectations ex one-off gains. The mix however was weaker than expected largely due to a larger-than-expected drag from the corporate centre. Trends in Barclays UK were encouraging but the Investment Bank did not show the strong trends of US peers, which is a disappointment. Progress on capital was encouraging given the drag of the preference share redemption. Overall we don’t see these results as moving the investment case on significantly – upside to the shares from here, in our view, is dependent on moving forward on capital and completing the sale of the BAGL stake. Our rating is Sector Perform and price target GBp230.

BE11:18am

Barclays reported pre-tax of £1,682m vs consensus of £1,462m and our estimate of £1,408. This however included a few one-off gains on Visa (£98m) and a gain on an asset sale of £192m. Ex these items the Q1 pre-tax was £1,392m, so slightly below. This was partly due to a higher corporate centre drag than expected on lower treasury income.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Barclays UK – NIM guidance improved

Barclays UK was 5% at the pre-tax level ex the Visa gain with provisions in line with our expectations and better NIM to 369bp in Q1 2017. Barclays upgraded its NIM guidance to c.360bp (assuming no change in base rate).

BE11:18am

Investment Bank – rates a drag

The investment £790m pre-tax was 5% below our forecast of £830m. The total IB revenue lines beat our forecasts by 2%. Fixed income was 2% below our forecasts as better-than-expected credit revenues were offset by lower-than-expected Macro revenues. Fixed income was down -1% YoY and up +16% QoQ. Investment Banking fees drove the 2% revenue beat and rose 51% YoY. This was offset by higher costs than expected partly due to the compensation awards change in Q4 16.

BE11:18am

Consumer cards and payments

CCP was 9% below expectations excluding the one-off gains. Loan-loss provisions were down on Q4 16 levels and only slightly above our forecasts.

Non-Core better than expectations

The drag from Non-Core was lower than expected at £241m vs £396m pre-tax loss in consensus.

11:18 am
BE11:19am

Capital ratio up 10bp QoQ

The capital ratio at 12.5% was in line with expectations up 10bp QoQ, which is a good result given the impact of the pref buy-back in the quarter (13bp drag) and was helped by lower RWAs in Non-Core and retained profits. Barclays remains confident on the execution of the disposal of BAGL, which it expects to add around 75bp. The TBV increased by 2p to 292p.

PM11:19am

Interesting there on the net interest margin. I hadnt appreciated how far that had improved at UK banks

PM11:19am

369 basis points

11:20 am
BE11:20am

(@Boncoeur: yep, that's the one. Just north of Oberkampf. Lovely bit of town.)

BE11:21am

So anyway, we're looking at good headline but largely one-off. Trading revenue weakish. Shares stop travelling. That's Barclays.

undefined
11:21 am
BE11:21am

And to RBS, since we're about it.

PM11:21am

Rude not to

Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS:LSE): Last: 257.90, up 4.5 (+1.78%), High: 264.40, Low: 254.80, Volume: 8.88m
11:22 am
BE11:22am

Big beat against consensus, but mostly one-off in nature and ... stop me if you've heard this recently already.

BE11:22am

NatWest Markets is the driver here.

PM11:22am

???

11:23 am
BE11:23am

RBC can explain again, if you like.

BE11:23am

Total income increased 15%yoy, a 7% beat v consensus. If we strip out the IFRS volatility, FX losses and unwind on securitisations in the property portfolio, then the beat is 13% versus consensus. However, by division the majority of the beat is coming from NatWest Markets where revenue increased 83%yoy driven by very strong improvement in income in the Rates business. RBS anticipates lower operating profit in Q2 2017 reflecting reduced income in NatWest Markets. The Retail and Commercial divisions performed in line with consensus from a revenue perspective and the rest of the beat comes from lower-than-expected Capital Resolution income and the corporate centre- both of which are difficult to forecast.

Group NIM improved 5bps versus Q4 2016 with 8bps of improvement in the retail and commercial bank helped by deposit repricing. This is surprisingly positive, in our view, given the largely current-account-funded nature of RBS's business. RBS reports stable mortgage spreads in Q1.

BE11:23am

Adjusted operating expenses fell 15%yoy, a 5% beat v consensus. If we strip out the VAT recovery included in adjusted expenses the beat is lower at 3%. RBS has a target to reduce costs by £750m- at the Q1 level annualised it implies a reduction in costs of £900m. RBS has guided that costs will rise in Q2 in part due to the absence of the VAT recovery. RBS has a good track record on reducing costs, for which consensus gives it the benefit in numbers.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Loan impairments were very low at £46m and 70% better than consensus, representing 6bps cost of risk. This is a consistent trend among the UK banks beating on provisions in Q1. RBS's cost of risk remains much lower than peers helped by continued releases- in the quarter there was a £45m net release of provisions from capital resolution.

BE11:24am

CET1 capital ratio increased 70bps to 14.1% ahead of consensus at 13.7%. RWAs fell £6.5bn in line with expectations and the capital generation is due to better-than-expected profits. RBS booked £577m of restructuring costs in the quarter compared to our full-year estimate of £1.3bn- the run rate is higher than we expected. TBV was broadly flat at 297p in line with expectations.

PM11:24am

Blimey, really low impairments

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Hm. ....................

BE11:24am

Headlines around about RBS hitting the milestone of its first quarterly profit since ......................

BE11:24am

............................ 2015.

11:24 am
BE11:25am

Which isn't terribly impressive is it? I mean, it's 2017.

BE11:25am

Have Shore.

BE11:25am

For y/e Dec ’17 we currently forecast adj PBT of £4.2bn, adj dil EPS of 22.2p, no dividend and TNAVPS of 312p. Based on yesterday’s closing price of 224p and our current forecasts, RBS trades on a PER of 11.4x, no dividend yield and P/TNAV of 0.8x (RoTE of 7.3%). While the group continues to make progress at an underlying level, there remain a number of significant legacy issues that continue to overhang the investment case, including US RMBS settlement and agreeing the alternative proposals to a sale of Williams & Glyn. So, despite recording a Q1 statutory profit, it is expected that the full year result will be another year of losses (taking RBS to a decade of losses) before the group is anticipated by management to move back into profit in 2018. The shares are currently trading at a slight premium to our fair value estimate of 240p and hence we retain a neutral stance. HOLD

11:25 am
BE11:26am

Okay, bored with banks.

undefined
PM11:26am

hehehe

11:25 am
PM11:26am

So am I

PM11:26am

Tho to be fair, we don't cover them as much as we used to

PM11:26am

I suppose that's good news

11:26 am
PM11:26am

What else has caught your eye Bryce?

BE11:26am

We have more reverse fantasy M&A!

BE11:27am

(Which is not in reference to Gemalto, to be clear. Though we might mention the Scorchedfingers profit warning a bit later.)

11:27 am
PM11:27am

(Just for fun)

BE11:27am

Yesterday we had Exane dumping on the Diageo target theory.

BE11:28am

Today we have Citi dumping on the Imperial Brands target theory.

11:28 am
PM11:28am

Omg smile

BE11:28am

As in, the idea that Japan Tobacco will buy them.

BE11:28am

The only recent speculation around the theme, I think, was this Telegraph Questor column. http://www.telegra...moke-mirrors-will/

11:28 am
BE11:28am

On which Citi's done about 40 pages of tight analysis, which is a wee bit butterfly-on-wheel.

BE11:29am

But it's good stuff. Here's the working.

BE11:29am

Central to Citi's argument is the law requiring Japan's government to keep its JT stake at 33.3%.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Which makes buying Imps a problem. Mostly because it would push JT's net debt out to nearly 5x EBITDA.

BE11:31am

(@Kings: don't cut and paste other people's stuff here. Particularly when said stuff is about copyright infringement. Ta.)

BE11:31am

.... So, farewell JT's investment-grade credit rating. Hello junk.

11:00 am
PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

BE11:31am

But the one-third stake rule requires Japan's government to be on the hook, absent a law change.

BE11:31am

And Japan's a bit tight for cash at the moment so is more likely to be a seller of JT, not a buyer.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Citi's argument is that Imps, as a JT target, isn't worth rewriting either the law or the national strategy.

BE11:31am

JT, by overpaying for the likes of Natural American Spirit and such, has shown no sign that it wants cash. It wants long-term growth.

PM11:32am

This is all very fascinating, but it's also fantastical, surely

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Yup. Then there's the antitrust angle.

BE11:32am

The whole point of taking out Imps is that it'd mean four-to-three in Europe, which requires a carve-up agreement (probably with BAT) before the paperwork gets signed.

BE11:32am

And brands like JPS and Gauloises end up getting regionally split between acquirers, which is messy.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

Plus you have JT saying, repeatedly, that it doesn't want to be in the US market. As we've noted, repeatedly.

BE11:33am

Also, there's tax.

BE11:33am

Imps pays a blended 20%, which is very low. How it manages this is something of a mystery, and the worry here is that a breakup might let daylight into magic.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Citi's conclusion is that Imps doesn't cure JT's ills.

BE11:33am

At the moment, JT is suffering from the growth of iQos in Japan, and price wars in the U.K and Russia. Imperial has no technology that could help to compete with iQos, and splitting Imperial with BAT may actually make the U.K. and Russian price wars worse, since BAT is likely to buy Imperial’s assets in both markets, and it may well decide that it could afford to gain a bit of market share in both.

BE11:33am

(Iqos is the PMI-backed vape pipe. Heat not burn. Which might be better for you, maybe.)

11:33 am
BE11:34am

So after all that you drill down to an argument that £50 or whatever for Imps would boost JT's EPS.

BE11:34am

But so would a buyback.

BE11:34am

And buybacks are a lot trickier to make a mess of than M&A.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

We calculate that if JT bought back 400 mln shares, which would be a bit over 22% of the total, it would be 16% EPS accretive, in other words it would give the same accretion as an acquisition of Imperial would, and leave net debt /EBITDA at 2.2x, which would be perfectly manageable.

PM11:34am

hehehe

BE11:34am

It's a good, clear, logical note.

11:34 am
BE11:35am

Though as we know, there's no requirement for M&A to be good, nor clear, nor logical.

Imperial Brands PLC (IMB:LSE): Last: 3,789, down 31 (-0.81%), High: 3,829, Low: 3,772, Volume: 428.57k
PM11:35am

Do you think the Rabble got your butterfly-on-wheel reference

11:35 am
PM11:35am

You are citing Pope, no?

PM11:35am

You actually got Alexander Pope into a Markets Live session

BE11:35am

I've no idea if they get most of what I type each day. It's mostly pearls before swine, innit?

11:35 am
PM11:36am

That's truly heroic Bryce

PM11:36am

I'll get the full quote, f

PM11:36am

Let Sporus tremble –"What? that thing of silk,
Sporus, that mere white curd of ass's milk?
Satire or sense, alas! can Sporus feel?
Who breaks a butterfly upon a wheel?
Yet let me flap this bug with gilded wings,
This painted child of dirt that stinks and stings;
Whose buzz the witty and the fair annoys,
Yet wit ne'er tastes, and beauty ne'er enjoys,

11:36 am
BE11:37am

And pearls before swine is from the Sermon on the Mount, if we're very keen on attributing sources.

undefined
PM11:37am

Difficult to follow that

11:37 am
PM11:37am

Mega M&A and Pope

BE11:37am

We do go off at tangents sometimes, don't we?

BE11:37am

Let's go back to the day job, such as it is.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

There's Drax, which usually gets some attention on the right for reasons I've never quite understood.

Drax Group PLC (DRX:LSE): Last: 326.10, up 22.2 (+7.31%), High: 333.70, Low: 314.70, Volume: 985.39k
BE11:39am

ROTR seem to like their clean dark spreads and Louisiana feedstock subsidies. Anyway, it's up on Barclays turning positive.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Post-results stock weakness unjustified - upgrading to Overweight: Drax's shares have fallen 20% post their mid-Feb results announcement, underperforming the SX6P by 24%; seemingly on little more than disappointment that Drax didn't immediately announce a new higher dividend policy, but instead said it would consult with shareholders over 1H17. We understand Drax's consultation is a genuine attempt to balance priorities of growth capex and increased returns to shareholders. We thus see no justification for the scale of Drax's recent share price reversion, and upgrade to OW.

BE11:40am

Post-results regulatory changes and acquisitions are positives: Since Drax’s results UK power prices are broadly unchanged – down slightly over the highly hedged near term & largely flat from Winter 2018/19; with sterling-denominated coal prices down 4.5%. There have been two main developments, both of which are positive: 1) Ofgem announced proposed changes for embedded benefits – likely resulting in higher capacity payments for Drax’s coal operations and OCGT projects; and 2) Drax’s acquisition of US biomass pellet plant capacity at 3.25x EV/EBITDA, which we see as earnings/valuation-accretive.

BE11:40am

June CMD a possible catalyst: Drax plans to hold a CMD in June; we see this as a possible positive catalyst – especially if it announces a new progressive dividend policy. We also hope to gain greater insight into Drax’s post-2027 strategy at this event.

11:40 am
BE11:41am

Increasing PT to 410p: We update forecasts for latest guidance and wholesale energy prices, increasing our PT from 400p to 410p. Though not riskless – particularly on post-2027 strategy (by which time we project a c.£1.1bn net cash position on the current dividend policy) – we estimate: greater than 70% of Drax 2018 EBITDA comes from the low-risk (ie low wholesale power exposure) areas of CFD subsidised biomass, retail and pellet plants; with almost none from higher risk coal – pre-capacity payments boosting coal earnings from 2019. Whilst Drax’s post-2027 future remains opaque at this stage, we estimate attractive high-teens to low-20% FCF yields over 2018-27, with FCF totalling 2.0x current market cap to 2027 – providing options to both increase shareholder returns and invest in quality assets to enhance its post-2027 outlook. Note our near-term EPS forecasts decrease predominantly due to accelerated depreciation, not a deterioration in fundamentals.

PM11:42am

Who is still using coal, any idea?

BE11:42am

I've not.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Neither have I had a good look at this Louisiana Pellets deal Drax has just had cleared

BE11:43am

450,000 tonnes p.a. of woodchips.

PM11:43am

The UK went a day recently without any coal-fired-electricity

11:43 am
PM11:44am

https://www.ft.com...-8691-d5f7e0cd0a16

BE11:44am

..... coo.

PM11:44am

Engineers in the National Grid control room watched the share of electricity from the country’s shrinking number of coal power plants sink to zero at about 11pm on Thursday night.

It stayed that way until midnight on Friday, making it the first working day in which no electricity came from the fossil fuel that has been a bedrock of the UK’s energy system since the first steam-driven public power station opened in the 1880s.

11:44 am
PM11:44am

Meanwhile in the US I think Trump wants to encourage coal use

undefined
PM11:45am

Gemalto metioned again on the right

11:46 am
PM11:46am

It's down just over 10 per cent currently

BE11:46am

Hm ... "Gemalto a sitting duck for PE bid", says @Blue Horseshoe.

PM11:46am

Scorchedfingers jsut a little

11:46 am
BE11:46am

"Hope springs eternal in the human breast; Man never Is, but always To be blest. "

BE11:46am

That's Pope as well.

PM11:46am

hehehe

11:46 am
BE11:46am

We're themed today.

BE11:47am

So, profit warning.

BE11:47am

And a strategic review to go with.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

The backdrop here is that Gemalto's had the perception of slipping behind the curve for some time.

BE11:48am

A trade sale was, or is, one option.

BE11:48am

Self help is another.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

And I don't think the punters recently going knee-deep in this thing were betting on the latter.

BE11:48am

Here's UBS.

BE11:49am

Gemalto announced Q1 sales broadly in-line with the update from March 22 nd (-8% constant currency y-o-y vs. guide of -7% to -9%) but due to some key issues (inventory reduction in US payments and mobile SIM share), the company is revising lower its FY profit from ops (PFO) guidance by 7% at the mid-point or we estimate c10-12% on an underlying basis (ex. the 3M contribution). It is also worth noting that the growth drivers of the business are off to a slow start in Q1'17: enterprise +1%, government flat, M2M -1% y-o-y although are expected to improve in H2. Positively the company is taking action on cost - initiating a €50m efficiency program. We would expect the shares to be under pressure today although actions on cost may help somewhat.

11:48 am
BE11:49am

Along with the weaker start in the growth businesses, the key challenges the company is facing are: 1) Mobile SIM competition and market share loss as operators push-out upgrading removable SIMs (Gemalto would typically do well in upgrades but likely less well when price competition rises on mature technologies) and instead focus on next-gen connectivity (embedded SIM). 2) In US payments, post the initial ramp up for EMV, the industry is going through an inventory reduction effort from 9-12 months to operate with 3-6 months - significantly impacting the H1 outlook.

BE11:49am

The implied headline FY PFO guide is now €390-450m (€90-100m H1 and €300-350m H2), giving a mid-point of €420m, a c7% cut at the mid-point from the prior €453m guide (UBSe €473m). This includes a contribution from the acquisition of 3M Identity business (we assume somewhere in the range of €10-20m to H2) and also restructuring efforts (€50m annualised target, we would estimate this has a €10-15m help in H2). In summary, in our view this is an underlying cut to guidance (ex. 3M) of around 10-12%.

BE11:49am

We would expect that the shares will be under pressure today and would note the 7% headline reduction in PFO guidance and our estimate this is a 10-12% reduction to underlying guidance (we would expect consensus was in-line with prior guide).

11:49 am
BE11:50am

(@BBOC: it usually means resetting costs to match sales, doesn't it? Which can, of course, form into a vicious cycle.)

BE11:51am

And Morgan Stanley.

BE11:51am

While we are conscious that recent downgrades may be the result of an attempt by new management to put numbers on a more credible footing, they also suggest a lack of visibility on several areas of the business. Today's statement also highlights weak revenue in the removable SIM business, and lower expectations, which may be the result of introductions of eSIM expected over the next 1-2 years. Our recent conversations with industry players suggest business models are in the early stages of being formed here, so management is likely framing conservatively.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

They're on a €60.00 target, which looks ambitious right now.

undefined
PM11:52am

Thanks for all that

11:52 am
BE11:53am

Could mention Geencore.

BE11:53am

Down another 4%.

Greencore Group PLC (GNC:LSE): Last: 220.70, down 8.3 (-3.62%), High: 229.70, Low: 219.80, Volume: 2.25m
11:53 am
BE11:53am

Sold off earlier in the week on news that the main customer of its recently acquired US business, Tyson Foods, was buying AdvancePierre.

BE11:54am

Still not entirely clear what's going to happen there.

BE11:55am

Lots of folk saying "long-term relationships don't get unpicked quickly" and etc. But it does certainly put a bit of negotiation pressure on Peacocks when its biggest customer has insourced the main rival.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

The further leg down today is on Starbucks figures.

BE11:55am

Sales weak.

BE11:56am

Global growth of 3% vs 3.6% consensus.

11:56 am
BE11:57am

You'll remember Starbucks keeps trying to expand its food yet somehow has ignored that it is uniformly terrible.

BE11:57am

All they need to do is buy a toaster! it's bizarre.

PM11:57am

What?

11:57 am
BE11:57am

What do you want with coffee? You want toast!

PM11:57am

Oh I see!

PM11:58am

Yes

11:58 am
BE11:58am

What do you get? You get a semi-plastic bun that's been sitting in a box in the back room for a week, or you get a cheese and ham sandwich that gets eviscerated by a Corby trouser press.

BE11:59am

It's terrible. And it's so easy to fix. Just buy a bloody toaster.

BE11:59am

Anyway. Here's Goodbody.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Greencore is due to report its H1 results on May 23rd. We anticipate the strong outturn indicated at the time of the Q1 trading update to have continued, driven by robust underlying growth in UK Food-to-Go, aided by the benefit of new contracts coming on-stream.

undefined
PM12:00pm

What's Google going to open up at?

12:00 pm
PM12:00pm

Alphabet

PM12:00pm

And when is some sort of anti-trust move going to get going?

PM12:00pm

It will be back through 1000 no doubt soon

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Up more than 4% premarket.

PM12:01pm

Did you see the figures -- a company of this size with Q1 revenues up another 20%

PM12:01pm

Together with Facebook it is quite literally taking all the ad money

12:02 pm
PM12:02pm
